verses.text: Abraham was now old, and advanced in years, and the LORD had blessed Abraham in every way.
verses.comment: Abraham’s blessings are a fulfillment of God’s covenant. The reference to his age and blessing sets the context for the story of Isaac’s marriage, which is crucial for the promise’s continuation.

verses.text: Abraham said to his senior servant, the one in charge of all he owned, 'Place your hand under my thigh,'
verses.comment: Placing a hand under the thigh was an ancient oath ritual, signifying a solemn and binding promise, possibly symbolizing a sacred trust connected to descendants.

verses.text: 'And I will have you swear by the LORD, the God of heaven and the God of earth, that you will not take a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites among whom I live.'
verses.comment: Abraham’s concern for separating his family from pagan influence prefigures the Biblical call to holiness and purity in choosing partners. There is also an implication about spiritual continuity and the future of a chosen people.

verses.text: 'Go instead to my country and my relatives, and take a wife for my son Isaac.'
verses.comment: Abraham wants Isaac’s wife to be from his own kin, ensuring the line stays within the covenant. This foreshadows the importance of spiritual kinship and unity in faith communities.

verses.text: The servant replied, 'What if the woman is not willing to come back with me to this land? Must I take your son back to the land you came from?'
verses.comment: The servant’s question shows the seriousness and uncertainty of the task. The priority remains: Isaac must not leave the Promised Land.

verses.text: Abraham said to him, 'Be careful that you do not take my son back there.'
verses.comment: Abraham’s insistence highlights the importance of remaining within the land of promise, echoing theological themes of faith and obedience.

verses.text: 'The LORD, God of heaven, who took me from my father’s house and from my native land, and who spoke to me and swore to me, saying, ‘To your offspring I will give this land’—He will send His angel before you, and you will take a wife for my son from there.'
verses.comment: Abraham’s faith in God’s provision (through an angel) is stressed. Divine guidance in vocation and marriage is a foundational Biblical theme, typologically pointing to God’s active providence in salvation history.

verses.text: But if the woman is not willing to come back with you, you are released from this oath; only, do not take my son back there.
verses.comment: Abraham’s caution preserves both the promise and his son, showing a balance of human responsibility and trust in God.

verses.text: So the servant put his hand under the thigh of Abraham his master and swore to him concerning this matter.
verses.comment: This formal oath represents serious commitment and a ritual pointing to continuity and sacred duty.

verses.text: Then the servant took ten of his master’s camels and departed, taking all kinds of valuable gifts from his master’s hand. He set out for Aram Naharaim, to the town of Nahor.
verses.comment: The journey and gifts show the seriousness with which the matter is pursued; gifts prefigure dowries and marital covenants, pointing to sacramental signs.

verses.text: He made the camels kneel beside the well outside the town, toward evening, at the time when women go out to draw water.
verses.comment: Wells are places of encounter throughout Scripture—foreshadowing themes of vocation and divine appointment.

verses.text: And he prayed, 'LORD, God of my master Abraham, let me succeed today and show kindness to my master Abraham.'
verses.comment: The servant’s prayer emphasizes faithfulness and dependence on divine initiative—later echoed in the Church’s teaching on vocation and providence.

verses.text: 'See, I am standing by this well of water, and the daughters of the townspeople are coming out to draw water.'
verses.comment: This detail connects to biblical motifs of meeting spouses by wells, as with Jacob and Moses, reinforcing divine guidance in key life moments.

verses.text: 'Let it be that the young woman to whom I say, “Please let down your jar that I may drink,” and who replies, “Drink, and I will water your camels also”—let her be the one you have chosen for your servant Isaac. By this I will know that you have shown kindness to my master.'
verses.comment: The servant seeks a providential sign, indicating humility, hospitality, and generosity—key virtues in biblical marriage.

verses.text: Before he had finished speaking, Rebekah, who was born to Bethuel son of Milcah, the wife of Abraham's brother Nahor, came out with her water jar on her shoulder.
verses.comment: God answers the servant’s prayer immediately, underlining divine initiative even before humans act (typology with Annunciation: Luke 1:26-38).

verses.text: The young woman was very beautiful, a virgin; no man had been with her. She went down to the well, filled her jar, and came up again.
verses.comment: Rebekah’s purity is emphasized, echoing themes of chosen vessels in Biblical history (hyperlink to Luke 1:27—Mary’s virginity).

verses.text: The servant ran to meet her and said, 'Please let me drink a little water from your jar.'
verses.comment: The servant takes a humble approach, beginning the test for God’s guidance.

verses.text: 'Drink, my lord,' she said, and quickly lowered her jar to her hand and gave him a drink.
verses.comment: Rebekah’s generosity fulfills the servant’s sought sign and manifests virtue.

verses.text: When she had finished giving him a drink, she said, 'I will also draw water for your camels until they have finished drinking.'
verses.comment: Her service goes beyond expectation, pictured as a model of charity and grace.

verses.text: She quickly emptied her jar into the trough, then ran back to the well to draw more water, and drew enough for all his camels.
verses.comment: The repetition of her action emphasizes industry and zeal—virtues encouraged for all believers.

verses.text: Without saying a word, the man watched her closely to determine whether the LORD had made his journey successful.
verses.comment: The silence shows reverence and discernment, a biblical approach to major decisions.

verses.text: When the camels had finished drinking, the man took out a gold nose ring weighing half a shekel and two gold bracelets weighing ten shekels, and placed them on her arms.
verses.comment: The jewelry represents both betrothal and honor, paralleling sacred symbols used in liturgical and marital settings.

verses.text: He asked, 'Whose daughter are you? Is there room in your father's house for us to spend the night?'
verses.comment: Requesting hospitality is a practice found throughout Scripture, underlying community and familial bonds.

verses.text: She replied, 'I am the daughter of Bethuel, the son that Milcah bore to Nahor.'
verses.comment: This genealogy confirms the suitability as Abraham wished, preserving covenant lineage.

verses.text: She added, 'We have plenty of straw and feed, as well as room for you to spend the night.'
verses.comment: Rebekah’s hospitality fulfills the biblical command to welcome the stranger (see Heb. 13:1-2).

verses.text: The man bowed down and worshiped the LORD.
verses.comment: Gratitude in worship is the appropriate response to answered prayer, highlighting prayer’s role in discernment.

verses.text: Saying, 'Blessed be the LORD, God of my master Abraham, who has not abandoned His steadfast love and faithfulness toward my master. As for me, the LORD led me on the journey to the house of my master’s relatives.'
verses.comment: Steadfast love and faithfulness are key covenant themes, echoed repeatedly in Scripture and liturgy.

verses.text: The young woman ran and told her mother’s household about these things.
verses.comment: The emphasis on the maternal household reflects matriarchal influence, also seen in biblical tradition.

verses.text: Now Rebekah had a brother named Laban, and Laban ran out to the man at the well.
verses.comment: Laban will reappear in Jacob’s story. The attention to family points to communal discernment in marriage.

verses.text: As soon as he saw the nose ring and the bracelets on his sister’s arms, and heard Rebekah explain what the man had said, he went out to the man, who stood by the camels at the well.
verses.comment: The gifts elicit interest; the role of signs and gifts in covenant relationships is significant in salvation history (see Gen. 15:7-10).

verses.text: He said, 'Come, you who are blessed by the LORD. Why are you standing out here? I have prepared the house and a place for the camels.'
verses.comment: Welcome and honor to those favored by the Lord is a sign of piety and hospitality.

verses.text: So the man came to the house, and the camels were unloaded, provided straw and feed, and water was brought to wash his feet and the feet of the men who were with him.
verses.comment: Foot washing is an act of hospitality, and later is linked to humility and service by Christ (John 13:14-15).

verses.text: Food was set before him, but he said, 'I will not eat until I have told you what I have to say.' Laban said, 'Speak.'
verses.comment: The servant prioritizes mission over personal comfort, reflecting biblical discipline in fulfilling God’s tasks.

verses.text: He said, 'I am Abraham’s servant.'
verses.comment: Identity in service is highlighted, paralleling the concept of the believer’s vocation in the New Testament.

verses.text: 'The LORD has greatly blessed my master, and he has become wealthy. He has given him flocks and herds, silver and gold, male and female servants, camels, and donkeys.'
verses.comment: Material blessing as a sign of covenant faithfulness, though not the ultimate goal, serves as a witness to God’s providence.

verses.text: 'Sarah, my master’s wife, bore him a son in her old age, and my master has given him everything he owns.'
verses.comment: Provision through miraculous birth points to God's sovereign initiative (see parallels in messianic foreshadowing).

verses.text: 'My master made me swear, saying, “You must not take a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites whose land I inhabit.”'
verses.comment: Repeated emphasis on marital purity and vocation, foundational to understanding spiritual lineage.

verses.text: 'But go to my father’s house and to my family, and take a wife for my son there.'
verses.comment: Community discernment in marriage remains vital; links to themes of spiritual progeny.

verses.text: 'I said to my master, “What if the woman is not willing to come with me?”'
verses.comment: Human uncertainty and deliberation are addressed, showing prudent engagement of free will with divine will.

verses.text: 'He answered me, “The LORD, in whose presence I have walked, will send His angel with you and make your journey successful, so that you may take a wife for my son from my family and my father’s house.”'
verses.comment: Reference to angelic guidance points ahead to God’s providential involvement in history and personal vocation.

verses.text: 'Then you will be free from my oath if you go to my family and they refuse to give her to you. You will be released from the oath.'
verses.comment: Release from the oath in case of refusal preserves both freedom and integrity, reflecting the role of consent in covenant.

verses.text: 'Today I came to the well and said, “LORD, God of my master Abraham, if you will make my journey successful—'
verses.comment: Direct quoting of prior prayer highlights the importance of prayerful discernment and recounting God’s work.

verses.text: 'See, I am standing at the well. If a young woman comes out to draw water, and I say to her, “Please let me drink a little water from your jar,”'
verses.comment: Prayerful request and test, again underlining dependence on divine providence.

verses.text: 'If she says to me, “Drink, and I will also draw water for your camels,” let her be the woman the LORD has chosen for my master’s son.'
verses.comment: The criteria for choosing emphasize charity and service: a sign of true vocation.

verses.text: 'Before I had finished praying in my heart, Rebekah came out with her jar on her shoulder. She went down to the well and drew water. I said to her, “Please give me a drink.”'
verses.comment: The immediacy of answer before prayer ends highlights God’s foreknowledge and will.

verses.text: 'She quickly lowered her jar and said, “Drink, and I will also water your camels.” So I drank, and she also watered my camels.'
verses.comment: Rebekah’s generosity, highlighted again as fulfillment of divine sign.

verses.text: 'I asked her, “Whose daughter are you?” She replied, “The daughter of Bethuel, son of Nahor and Milcah.” Then I put the ring in her nose and bracelets on her arms.'
verses.comment: The giving of jewelry is bridal imagery; in Isaiah, God uses similar imagery for Israel (Isa. 62:3-5).

verses.text: 'And I bowed down and worshiped the LORD. I blessed the LORD, God of my master Abraham, who led me faithfully to take the granddaughter of my master’s brother for his son.'
verses.comment: Repeated worship and blessing, showing prayerful reflection and continued thanksgiving.

verses.text: 'Now if you will show steadfast love and faithfulness to my master, tell me; and if not, let me know, so I may turn to the right or to the left.'
verses.comment: The servant seeks openness and clarity, respecting autonomy of choice, foundational for consent in Christian marriage.

verses.text: Laban and Bethuel answered, 'This is from the LORD; we cannot say anything to you one way or the other.'
verses.comment: Discernment of God’s will takes priority, with human assent—this submission to divine will echoes Mary’s fiat (Luke 1:38).

verses.text: 'Here is Rebekah; take her and go, and let her become the wife of your master’s son, as the LORD has directed.'
verses.comment: They give consent, recognizing the will of God—foreshadowing church teaching on discernment and marriage vocation.

verses.text: When Abraham’s servant heard their answer, he bowed down to the ground before the LORD.
verses.comment: Worship is again central; gratitude for fulfilled promise is a recurring theme in salvation history.

verses.text: The servant brought out gold and silver jewelry, and garments, and gave them to Rebekah. He also gave costly gifts to her brother and her mother.
verses.comment: Gift-giving as part of betrothal is both a symbol of honor and a legal transaction—the sacramental aspect of marriage foreshadowed.

verses.text: Then he and the men who were with him ate and drank and spent the night there. When they rose in the morning, he said, 'Let me go back to my master.'
verses.comment: The meal marks the sealing of agreement, paralleling the communal meals associated with covenant.

verses.text: 'But her brother and her mother said, “Let the young woman stay with us a few days—at least ten; then you may go.”'
verses.comment: A request for delay; family feelings and attachment balanced with call to vocation.

verses.text: But he replied, 'Do not hold me back, since the LORD has made my journey successful; send me on my way so I can go to my master.'
verses.comment: The urgency of mission and obedience to God’s call—parallels to apostolic summons in the New Testament.

verses.text: They said, 'Let’s call the young woman and ask her directly.'
verses.comment: Honoring personal consent reflects an essential aspect of Christian marriage: free will.

verses.text: They called Rebekah and asked her, 'Will you go with this man?' She replied, 'I will go.'
verses.comment: Her willing consent is reminiscent of the response to divine calling; parallels Mary’s fiat.

verses.text: So they sent their sister Rebekah, along with her nurse, and Abraham’s servant and his men.
verses.comment: The sending off with a nurse suggests both care and support, common in ancient and spiritual family structures.

verses.text: They blessed Rebekah, saying, 'May you, our sister, become thousands upon thousands, and may your offspring possess the gates of their enemies.'
verses.comment: The blessing predicts fruitfulness and victory. Possessing gates points to dominion—a messianic motif later fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: Then Rebekah and her attendants got ready, mounted their camels, and went with the man. So the servant took Rebekah and departed.
verses.comment: The journey is intentional and missional, paralleling vocations leaving old life for new roles within God’s purpose.

verses.text: Now Isaac had come from Beer-lahai-roi, for he was living in the Negev.
verses.comment: The detail about Isaac’s location ties together family stories and connects generations geographically.

verses.text: One evening, Isaac had gone out to meditate in the field, and looking up, he saw camels approaching.
verses.comment: Isaac’s meditation anticipates later scriptural models for prayer and contemplation.

verses.text: Rebekah looked up, saw Isaac, and got down from her camel.
verses.comment: Her action shows respect and anticipation—traditional gestures remain meaningfully symbolic in spiritual encounters.

verses.text: She asked the servant, 'Who is that man walking in the field to meet us?' The servant replied, 'He is my master.' So Rebekah took her veil and covered herself.
verses.comment: Veiling is a sign of modesty and betrothal, paralleled to spiritual mystery and tradition.

verses.text: The servant explained to Isaac all that he had done.
verses.comment: The detailed recounting affirms the importance of testimony and accountability.

verses.text: Isaac brought Rebekah into his mother Sarah’s tent, and she became his wife. He loved her, and Isaac was comforted after his mother’s death.
verses.comment: Marriage is presented as a sacramental union involving love, comfort, and continuity. Isaac’s love for Rebekah foreshadows Christ’s love for the Church (Eph. 5:32).
